text:
JAMES CALLOWAY: My name
is James W Calloway.
Austin Callaway, he's my cousin.
My dad's brother's son.

If you go back to the days when
lynching and beating and all

that stuff was going on, nobody
never got arrested for it
or charged with it.

LOUIS DEKMAR: Had discussions
with several members

of the African-American
community, NAACP,

and decided that a way to
address this historically past

event, which still shapes and
forms relationships today,

would be an acknowledgment
of the failure

of the police department
to protect Austin Calloway.

JIM THORNTON: We
come together tonight
to acknowledge an injustice.

Let me say emphatically,
justice failed Austin Calloway.

LOUIS DEKMAR: African-Americans,
alive decades ago,

can speak of incidents
of terror and lynching,

and share an oral history about
those times, which is passed
on to succeeding generations.

That history
reflects and includes

a litany of injustices
among a race of people

and a resulting
distrust of the police.

Austin Calloway's lynching
is a part of that history.

As the LaGrange police chief,
I sincerely regret and denounce

the role our police department
played in Austin's lynching,

both through our actions
and our inaction.

And for that, I'm
profoundly sorry.
It should never have happened.
[applause]

ERNEST WARD: On behalf
of the local NAACP

and the citizens
of Troup County,

we accept this acknowledgment
with an understanding

that this act is a
sincere intentional step,

as well as the beginning of
a journey of a much larger
initiative of trust building.

DEBORAH TATUM: I speak
your name, Austin Calloway,

and ask God for forgiveness
for the people that
did this inhumane thing to you.
[music playing]

JAMES CALLOWAY: To let
you know that somebody

really cares what happened
back then in those days.
